title: Threat of Hard-Hitting Russia Sanctions Leaves U.S. Companies Planning for All Scenarios
summary: Businesses with operations in Russia are grappling with whether sanctions may be imposed. U.S. companies with interests in Russia are rushing to draw up contingency plans as Washington threatens sanctions should President Vladimir Putin order troops into Ukraine.

title: U.S., Russia Square Off in Rare U.N. Security Council Debate
summary: Washington and allies say Russian goal is to destabilize Kyiv; Moscow fails to block debate and accuses U.S. of 'stoking tensions'. A senior U.S. diplomat accused Russia of trying to destabilize Ukraine, and a Kremlin representative in turn criticized Washington for stoking fears and tensions as the two sides squared off in a fractious debate in the United Nations Security Council.

title: New York Times Buys Wordle
summary: Media company says price paid for viral word game is in low-seven figures. The New York Times said it bought Wordle, the word game that has become an online phenomenon.

title: The 'Apartheid' Libel of Israel
summary: Amnesty International all but says the Jewish state shouldn't exist.. Perhaps you thought Israel had long ago established its right to exist as a Jewish state. Guess again. Hamas, Hezbollah and Iran want to eliminate Israel as we know it, but who would have thought they'd find allies in Amnesty International?

title: The Evidence on 'Free' Pre-K
summary: A Vanderbilt study finds negative results for children in Tennessee.. Democrats are looking to resurrect pieces of their Build Back Better plan, and a leading candidate is President Biden's $200 billion universal pre-K entitlement. So it's worth digesting new evidence that low-income children who attended a state pre-K program fared worse in sixth grade than similar children who didn't.

title: Another Covid Relief Bill?
summary: Any new spending vehicle will quickly balloon in size.. Where did the $1.9 trillion in last March's spending bill go? Apparently on things other than Covid relief. Health-care providers are begging the Biden Administration for more money. And Congress is cooking up another relief bill for small business, though it will never stop there.

title: Going After the Kremlin Mafia
summary: Putin's cronies need to know they won't be safe from sanctions.. One difficulty with crafting sanctions against Russia is finding ways to maximize pain for corrupt elites while minimizing damage to ordinary Russians, who suffer enough under Vladimir Putin's rule. But there are ways to hit the wallets of Mr. Putin's mafia-if Western governments have the political will to act.

title: FDA Fully Approves Moderna's Covid-19 Vaccine; U.S. Infections Fall
summary: Company's Spikevax shot had previously been available under emergency-use authorization. The Food and Drug Administration on Monday gave its full approval to Moderna Inc.'s Covid-19 vaccine, branded Spikevax, for use in adults 18 and older, making it the second fully approved Covid-19 vaccine after one from Pfizer Inc. and BioNTech SE.

title: Stocks Move Higher on Final Day of Tumultuous Month
summary: Despite Monday gains, S&P suffers worst monthly performance since March 2020. The S&P 500 rose Monday but closed out its worst month since March 2020 as expectations for higher interest rates erode enthusiasm for stocks.

title: Stemming a Sovereign-Debt Crisis
summary: Rising interest rates and slow economic growth will spur restructuring, but the procedures are inadequate for borrowers and lenders.. Rising interest rates and slowing global economic growth likely will spur many low-income countries to try to restructure their sovereign debt. This is troubling because recent restructuring cases have produced extended stalemates between borrowers and lenders rather than resolution. Existing international mechanisms for dealing with sovereign-debt restructuring simply aren't up to the task. Market participants urgently need to make reforms to prevent a deepening debt crisis in developing economies.

title: Everything You Need to Know About Wordle
summary: Everything you need to know about the online game that has taken the internet by storm. Wordle seems like it is everywhere these days. And now it has a new owner. The New York Times said on Jan. 31 that it was buying the viral online word game for a price in the low-seven figures. Here's what you need to know.

title: America Is Stronger Than It Looks
summary: Moves by China and Russia have bolstered the U.S. Indo-Pacific alliances and NATO.. The world's attention may be fixed on Russia's challenge to Ukraine, but the Biden administration faces something much larger: an intensifying challenge by China, Russia and opportunists such as Iran and North Korea to the global order that the U.S. inherited from a faltering British Empire in the 1940s. While Vladimir Putintightened his grip on Belarus and stepped up his war of nerves against Ukraine, China signaled its support for Russia's Ukraine policy, sent record numbers of fighter jets through Taiwan's defense zone, conducted joint naval drills with Russia near Japan, and beefed up its naval presence between Japan and Taiwan. While China's ambassador to the U.S. warned of a growing danger of war over the island, Jin Canrong, a leading Chinese academic with extensive contacts in the Chinese Communist Party, predicted that China would carry out an "armed unification" with Taiwan by 2027.

title: Inflation Drives Wages Down, Not Up
summary: The 'wage-price spiral' is a myth. It's much easier to raise prices than wages.. The Labor Department released a report Friday showing that worker pay increased about 4% in one year, the fastest rate in two decades. This led to predictable alarm that the U.S. is facing a "wage-price spiral," in which higher wages push up prices, which lead to demands for still-higher wages, and so forth. But the wage-price spiral is a false and antiquated economic idea that refuses to die and keeps generating bad policies.

title: I Can Live Without a Living Room
summary: Other than delivering news of a death in the family, there isn't much it's good for.. Charlotte, N.C.

title: 'Queens of Jerusalem' Review: Crusading Women
summary: The extreme patriarchy of the age made life during the Crusades miserable for women. Not that it was much better for the men.. Anyone schooled in the history of the Crusades will know of Steven Runciman, arguably the 20th century's leading popular authority on the period. Interminable, relentlessly detailed and compulsively readable, his canonical three-volume "A History of the Crusades" (1951-54) set the standard-an enduring achievement of manic storytelling.

title: Judge Rejects Plea Deal for Man Who Killed Ahmaud Arbery
summary: Travis McMichael's proposed deal to avert hate-crimes trial was denounced by Arbery's family. A federal judge rejected a plea agreement Monday that would have averted a hate-crimes trial for the man convicted of murdering Ahmaud Arbery.

title: Deploy Tough Sanctions and Diplomacy to Isolate the Houthis in Yemen
summary: The radicals and their backers are attacking a new vision of a peaceful future for the Middle East.. On Sunday night, in their third attack in as many weeks, Houthi radicals in Yemen unleashed a new barrage of ballistic and cruise missiles and weaponized drones against civilian sites across the United Arab Emirates.

title: Biden to Designate Qatar as 'Major Non-NATO Ally'
summary: Strengthening of ties comes as U.S. seeks energy supplies for Europe if Russia invades Ukraine. WASHINGTON-The Biden administration is designating Qatar to be a special U.S. ally as it presses Doha for assurances the country could help provide energy supplies to Europe if Russia invades Ukraine.

title: FTC Warns Social Media Users About Targeted Advertising as Scams Abound
summary: Antifraud specialists and marketing executives say opting out will make minimal difference in the fight against con artists online. Scams that originate on social media, from fake Instagram Shops to false online romances that lead to extortion, ballooned between 2020 and 2021, according to a new report from the Federal Trade Commission. Targeted advertising looks like it has something to do with it, the agency said.

title: U.S. Sanctions Myanmar Officials, Port Business on Coup Anniversary
summary: Sanctions against a Myanmar port operator and several individuals with alleged ties to the government and military come about a year after a coup overturned a civilian-led government headed by Aung San Suu Kyi. The U.S. Treasury Department is sanctioning seven individuals and a port operator with alleged ties to the Myanmar military regime that seized power in a coup last year.

title: Canada Says Trucker Vaccine Mandate Hasn't Dented Border Crossings
summary: Volume of trucks entering Canada is steady but an industry group says importers are paying more to move U.S. produce into the country. OTTAWA-Canada's transport minister said a Covid-19 vaccine mandate that targets truckers crossing the U.S.-Canada border has had little impact on the volume of trailers entering the country to deliver goods.

title: Dolce & Gabbana to Stop Using Fur in Its Designs
summary: Gucci, Prada have instituted similar bans; Louis Vuitton sells a $25,900 mink logo hoodie. Fur is increasingly falling out of favor at luxury fashion houses.

title: Qatar Airways Launches New Boeing Cargo Jet
summary: Middle Eastern carrier boosts 777X and plans to take Boeing 737 MAX planes after dispute with Airbus. Qatar Airways has agreed to buy up to 50 of Boeing Co. 's new 777X freighter jets, the White House said Monday, with the carrier launching the plane during a boom in air cargo.

title: 'Laurel Hell' by Mitski Review: A Dark yet Buoyant Journey
summary: The sixth album from the indie darling is chillier than its predecessors, but her poetic craft remains ever present..

title: 'Maus' Tops Amazon Best-Seller List After Tennessee School Board Pulls Graphic Novel
summary: Board's decision about Pulitzer Prize-winning book on Holocaust drew backlash. "Maus," a graphic novel about the Holocaust published decades ago, reached the top of Amazon.com Inc.'s bestsellers list after a Tennessee school board's decision to remove the book spurred criticism nationwide.

title: Investors Sour on Muni Funds
summary: Expectations for rising interest rates spur outflows; returns have fallen. Investors pulled $1.4 billion from municipal bond funds in the week ended last Wednesday, the biggest weekly outflow since the early days of the pandemic, according to Refinitiv Lipper.

title: Sony to Buy 'Halo' Creator Bungie in $3.6 Billion Deal
summary: Agreement to purchase the studio behind the Halo and Destiny franchises follows Microsoft's move to acquire Activision Blizzard. Sony Group Corp.'s videogame unit said Monday that it is buying videogame developer Bungie Inc., the studio that created the Halo and Destiny franchises, in a deal valued at $3.6 billion.

title: NATO Leaders Flock to Ukraine as Russia Masses Troops
summary: British, Dutch, Polish prime ministers and Turkish president all slated to fly to Kyiv; some offering weapons supplies. Several Western leaders and foreign ministers are scheduled to visit Kyiv in the coming days in a flurry of diplomatic activity that aims to deter a possible Russian invasion of Ukraine and find a peaceful way out of the crisis.

title: Neil Young Pushes Amazon Music After Pulling Content From Spotify
summary: Musician offers link where new Amazon Music subscribers can receive four months free, then pay $7.99 a month afterward for streaming service. Neil Young has directed his fans to use Amazon Music to stream his songs after he pulled his music from Spotify Technology SA last week over his objection to what he says is Covid-19 misinformation spread by podcaster Joe Rogan.

title: EPA Moves to Restore Obama-Era Rules on Power Plants
summary: Agency says controlling toxic emissions reduces cancer risks and neurodevelopmental delays in children. The Environmental Protection Agency on Monday moved to restore a federal determination that allowed it to regulate mercury, lead and other toxic metals from coal-fired and oil-fired power plants.

title: Apollo Buys Minority Stake in 'Dune' Producer Legendary Entertainment
summary: China's Dalian Wanda Group will remain majority shareholder in Legendary Entertainment. Apollo Global Management Inc. is buying a minority stake in Legendary Entertainment, the latest in a series of deals struck by Hollywood firms cashing in on the growing demand for streaming content.

title: Cheslie Kryst, Former Miss USA, Dies After Falling From NYC Apartment Building
summary: Police are investigating the death of the former civil litigation attorney and entertainment correspondent as a possible suicide. Police are investigating the death of Cheslie Kryst, a former Miss USA who died after falling from a New York City high-rise building, as a possible suicide.

title: Positive Reinforcement (Tuesday Crossword, February 1)
U.S., U.K. Prepare Plans to Sanction Russian Oligarchs, Businesses
summary: Washington is drafting a list of Kremlin allies that could be blacklisted if Russia invades Ukraine, and the U.K. is proposing a new sanctions law. The U.S. and U.K. governments plan to target Russian oligarchs and businesses connected to the Kremlin as part of a broad sanctions effort designed to punish Moscow in case Russia invades Ukraine.

title: He Who Must Not Be Named in Swing Districts
summary: Can Democrats avoid being associated with the president?. Many U.S. voters aren't inclined to say something nice about President Joe Biden. Many Democratic candidates have decided it's best to say nothing at all. Fortunately for the president, at least for the moment he appears to be maintaining solid support within the Biden household.

title: Johnson's Downing Street Criticized in Report Over Parties During Lockdowns
summary: Gatherings shouldn't have happened, says government report, citing failures of leadership. LONDON-British police are investigating two gatherings at Prime Minister Boris Johnson's residence during a Covid-19 lockdown, a government report said Monday, strengthening the hand of rebellious lawmakers in his Conservative Party who are seeking to oust the British leader.

title: Operation Warp Speed Slowly Gets Its Due
summary: The program's premature abandonment left the country unprepared for the Delta and Omicron Covid waves.. The Trump administration's Operation Warp Speed delivered three Covid-19 vaccines in record time. Yet liberals are giving the program its due only now, amid President Biden's Covid-19 stumbles. Some, including former Biden adviser Ezekiel Emanuel, are even calling for another Operation Warp Speed to boost therapies. Operation Warp Speed also delivered the two monoclonal antibody treatments. More such treatments would have been available this winter had the Biden team not abandoned the program.

title: Covid Restrictions and Other Overreach Bring America Toward a Libertarian Moment
summary: Trillion-dollar spending, onerous regulations and even censorship haven't ended the pandemic.. The rising fear among American conservatives since the early days of the Covid pandemic has been that the nation would emerge from the crisis significantly less free.

title: Spotify's Fate Is in the Stars
summary: Market-value swing from controversy between Joe Rogan and Neil Young underscores new level of risk from podcast focus. Whatever else Joe Rogan may be, no one should accuse him of not being a team player.

title: Equity Alliance, Investor in Minority- and Female-Led Venture Funds, Raises $28.6 Million
summary: Chaired by former Time Warner CEO Richard Parsons, the fund of funds is backed by luminaries of the venture and business worlds and joins a number of other efforts aimed at democratizing access to capital. Equity Alliance, a new firm backed by boldface names in business and venture capital, has closed a $28.6 million fund to invest in venture funds led by women and minority managers.

title: What to Know About Supreme Court Nomination Process
summary: Here is a look at process to nominate and confirm a successor as Justice Stephen Breyer goes into retirement. Supreme Court Justice Stephen Breyer, who has served nearly three decades on the court, said Jan. 27 in a letter to President Biden that he plans to retire at the end of the current term.

title: How Europe-Not Trump-Corroded NATO
summary: No wonder Putin assesses that the alliance is divided and now is the time for him to act.. Tom Rogan's op-ed "Is Germany a Reliable Ally? Nein" (Jan. 24) and your editorial "Deterrence Message to Moscow" (Jan. 25) correctly highlight why NATO's Ukraine strategy likely will fail. There will be two owners for this failure.

title: A Chinese Competitor Tried to Trigger a Backlash Against Chanel. It Backfired.
summary: Cosmetics maker Forest Cabin initiated social-media posts targeting the French luxury brand's use of red camellias. When Chanel SA started marketing a new cosmetics range using red camellias this month, a Chinese competitor took offense and accused the French luxury brand of appropriating the Asian flower.

title: Racial Preferences at the Supreme Court and in the Academy
summary: The progressives who oversee admissions on most campuses have too much invested in diversity, equity and inclusion to stop now.. Your editorial "Race, Harvard and the Supreme Court" (Jan. 25) argues that "the progressive zeal for divvying up people by race, ethnicity and sexuality has increased." But it is slavery, Jim Crow, lynching, the Ku Klux Klan and its followers (Proud Boys, Oath Keepers, QAnon), and persistent structural racism (exclusionary zoning, reliance on property taxes to pay for K-12 public education) that has long divvied up people by race and continues to do so today. Progressives wish they had such power.

title: How to Escape a Union? Ask to See Its Books
summary: The Professional Staff Congress Union at the City University of New York vilifies Israel. But there may be a way out.. A situation like Avraham Goldstein's was heard by the Supreme Court in 1988 ("I'm Stuck With an Anti-Semitic Labor Union," op-ed, Jan. 21). In Communications Workers of America v. Beck, the court ruled that union members can claim "financial core" status and pay only that percentage of dues that go to labor-related issues. By doing so, they gain the right to require the union to open its books for an audit, to double check the union's calculations regarding what is and isn't work related.

title: Who Really Got Rich From the GameStop Revolution?
summary: During a revolt against Wall Street, some pros still figured out a way to win. When Reddit became the rowdy center of the investing universe last January, its co-founder Alexis Ohanian called the frenzy a "revolution" and a "chance for Joe and Jane America, the retail buyers of stock, to flex back and push back." Maybe one day, he mused, the members of Reddit's WallStreetBets forum could do more than just ambush hedge funds-they could outperform those highly-paid investors.

title: We Can Run but Can't Hide From Covid
summary: Nothing a society does can keep this respiratory virus from being 'allowed' to infect people.. Profs. Michael Goldman and Stanley Maloy demonstrate the core problem with the government's response to Covid when they say it is "misguided to allow large numbers of people to become infected" (Letters, Jan. 21).

title: We Wouldn't Need Iran's Oil If Biden Let Us Drill at Home
summary: The president should reverse his disastrous executive orders.. It should not be necessary to yield concessions to Iran, and beg it to increase oil output, to lower the cost of oil ("Inflation Gives Biden an Incentive for a Bad Iran Deal" by Ilan Berman, op-ed, Jan. 20). A simpler solution is staring President Biden in the face: Reverse his disastrous executive orders and allow the U.S. to ramp up production of its own crude oil.

title: Exxon to Move Headquarters to Houston
summary: The oil giant will remain in Texas but consolidate operations as it reorganizes its business units. Exxon Mobil Corp. is moving its corporate headquarters from Irving, Texas, to Houston as part of a business reorganization that the company said will be completed by 2023.

title: BTS Star Jimin Tests Positive for Covid-19, Undergoes Surgery for Appendicitis
summary: K-Pop band member had successful procedure and is recovering in the hospital. Jimin, a member of the K-Pop boy band BTS, has tested positive for Covid-19 and underwent surgery for acute appendicitis, his management company said Monday.

title: Tax Haven U.A.E. to Introduce Levy on Corporate Profits
summary: New 9% tax rate will apply from June 1, 2023. Individuals will remain exempt from income and capital-gains taxes.. The United Arab Emirates is set to introduce a tax on corporate profits, as it juggles the need to remain attractive for international business with its agreement to support global tax transparency.

title: A Listening Deficit Plagues America
summary: The America Talks virtual event in April will try to address the problem, with conversations that seek understanding across political divides. As this election year begins to unfold, Americans aren't merely arguing about politics. It's increasingly clear they can't even agree on what they're arguing about.

title: Joe Rogan Apologizes, Spotify Publishes Content Policy After Neil Young Outcry
summary: Podcaster said he aims to be more balanced; Streaming giant creates Covid-19 information hub. Joe Rogan, responding to Neil Young's objections to his podcast and host Spotify, said his show has grown "out of control" and pledged to be more balanced and informed about controversial topics and guests.

title: China's Communist Party Quietly Inserts Itself Into Everyday Life
summary: A sprawling propaganda campaign that has gone virtually unnoticed outside the country is taking place in 'civilization' centers, new report finds. At a new Communist Party-built facility in Shanghai designed to cultivate civilized thought and behavior, a recent schedule of events led off with a speech about the city's role as site of the party's first official meeting in 1921.

title: Citrix Systems to Go Private in $16.5 Billion Deal
summary: Elliott's affiliate and Vista Equity to pay $104 a share for cloud-computing company. Citrix Systems Inc. will be taken private in an all-cash acquisition valued at $16.5 billion, including debt, making the cloud-computing company the latest subject of a big leveraged buyout following a surge in deals last year.

title: European Businesses Ride Out the Omicron Wave
summary: Covid-19 variant dented fourth-quarter growth, but effect was more muted than in previous surges. As Omicron loomed over Europe in December, Graham Cook braced for yet another blow to his bowling business in London, fearing a fourth lockdown, potentially without government support, would force him to cut costs.

title: Pinterest Adds Augmented Reality Feature for Home Decor
summary: The new tool expands on its existing technology used for beauty products. Pinterest Inc. is introducing a new augmented reality tool for home furniture, allowing consumers to see how the items would look in their homes via the company's mobile app.

title: That Blinking Office Voice Mail? Everyone Else Ignores It, Too.
summary: Even after some office workers have returned to their desks, the phones still flash with unchecked messages. Chris Galdieri hasn't checked his work voice mail in nearly two years and he isn't sorry.

title: Streamers Struggle to Keep Users Who Joined to Watch a Hit
summary: Roughly half of U.S. viewers who joined right after 'Hamilton' and 'Wonder Woman 1984' were gone in six months, data show. Streaming-video services get a surge of subscribers when they launch a hotly anticipated show or movie. But many of these new customers unsubscribe within a few months, according to new data, a challenge even for the industry's deep-pocketed giants.

title: Citrix, Spotify, Knightscope, Tesla: What to Watch in the Stock Market Today
summary: Citrix is nearing a deal to be taken private; Spotify made public its content policies. Wall Street indexes were mixed in morning trading. Here's what we're watching on Monday:

title: China's Star Skier Was Born in the USA-and Still Lives There
summary: Eileen Gu, a top contender in halfpipe, slopestyle and big-air events, competed as an American until switching affiliations in 2019. Eileen Gu looks like the apex high-achieving American teenager. She scored a 1580 out of a possible 1600 on the SAT. She got into Stanford. She models handbags for Louis Vuitton and jewelry for Tiffany & Co. And she dominates the freestyle skiing events of halfpipe, slopestyle and big air.

title: Wordle Has People Digging Out Old Games. Mastermind or Jotto, Anyone?
summary: The viral online word game can be played only once a day, so players are searching for their fix in childhood games. Last weekend, Josh Small did something he hasn't done in nearly a decade: play Mastermind.

summary: The alpine skier and Olympic gold medalist, 37, whose new memoir is called 'Rise: My Story,' shares what's on her phone.. Number of contacts

title: Ricky Gervais on Why No Subject Should Be Off-Limits in Comedy
summary: "I think a lot of this pious offense comes from people mistaking the target of the joke with the subject. You can joke about anything, but it depends on what the actual target is.". In our series My Monday Morning, self-motivated people tell WSJ. how they start off the week.

title: I Can't Believe It, but the Cincinnati Bengals Are in the Super Bowl
summary: A stunning comeback over Kansas City propels an unexpected team of destiny. Never a moment of doubt, right?

title: Extended Stay Hotels 'Print Money' for Investors in Covid-19 Downturn
summary: Demand for extended stay accommodations has been high during the pandemic and shows no signs of easing. Leisure travel flourished after Covid-19 lockdowns eased. Business travel is still depressed. But one type of lodging has filled rooms throughout the pandemic: extended stay hotels.

title: Ackman Made Billions on Pandemic Shutdown, Bounceback
summary: Two complex trades on the economy's swift shutdown and its fevered reopening netted almost $4 billion. As the coronavirus emerged, Bill Ackman made billions betting that the market was misjudging the virus's economic toll.

title: Fewer Goods Are Less Good for the Stock Market
summary: Shift in pandemic spending from services to stuff has boosted companies listed on stock markets, and a return to normal could hurt. Big public companies in the U.S. aren't particularly representative of American businesses at large. For much of the pandemic, that has been a blessing for the stock market. In the months ahead, it could be a curse.

title: Crashing Pot Stocks Are Flush With Cash
summary: Shares in U.S. marijuana companies are plunging, but they are less dependent on a bullish stock market than they used to be. Cannabis stocks are on a major downer. The only good news is that U.S. pot companies are better able to cope with low valuations than they were during the last crunch.

title: Russia-Ukraine Tensions Drive Global Wheat Prices Higher
summary: The two nations account for just under a third of global wheat exports, much of which goes to the Middle East to keep bread prices affordable. The threat of war between Russia and Ukraine is rattling international grain markets, driving wheat prices higher on both sides of the Atlantic and leaving traders girding for more volatility ahead.

title: University of California Sues 8minute Solar, Seeking $1.22 Billion
summary: Lawsuit by university regents alleges company and co-founder Tom Buttgenbach misappropriated funds from a $150 million investment. The University of California system is suing 8minute Solar Energy LLC and Tom Buttgenbach, its co-founder and chief executive, seeking roughly $1.22 billion over the university's investment in several renewable-power projects.

title: The Instagram Story Gets a Few More Wrinkles
summary: In rush to prevent teen attrition in the face of increasing competition, Instagram might be trying too much at once. Instagram might be having a midlife crisis. Symptoms include constantly comparing itself to others and dramatic changes in behavior and appearance. If only it could buy itself a shiny new sports car.

title: The Numbers Behind the NFL's Crazy Playoffs
summary: The Los Angeles Rams and Cincinnati Bengals advanced to meet in the Super Bowl after a historically dramatic postseason. The Cincinnati Bengals have spent most of their existence as football's comic foil. But when they somehow reached the Super Bowl for the first time in more than three decades, it somehow made perfect sense.

title: Evergrande Faces Forced Sale of Hong Kong Land It Pledged for Loan
summary: Oaktree Capital Management said to appoint receiver after developer defaulted on secured borrowing. Receivers have been appointed over land in Hong Kong that China Evergrande Group used as collateral for a $520 million loan, but the sale of the plot won't affect the company's broader restructuring, the troubled developer said.

title: Ex-Central Bank Chief Mark Carney Adds Consulting Role to Job Portfolio
summary: Carney, also the U.N.'s climate and finance envoy, will retain his role as an executive at Brookfield Asset Management. LONDON-Mark Carney, the former head of the central banks of the U.K. and Canada and the United Nations' point man on climate change and finance, has taken on a new role advising companies on the global economy with Macro Advisory Partners, a consulting firm.

title: Indian Stocks Still Need to Let Off Some Steam
summary: After a banner 2021, they have held up better than U.S. counterparts in 2022, but valuations still look stretched. Indian stock markets broke all sorts of records in 2021. Frothy valuations and economic headwinds may cap further upside this year.

title: Fed Nominee Has Focused His Research on Monetary Policy and Poverty
summary: Philip Jefferson would support raising interest rates to curb inflation, while considering impacts on different groups, associates say. WASHINGTON-Economist Philip Jefferson has called on the Federal Reserve to more closely consider how its policies shape the economic well-being of different groups of Americans. If confirmed for a seat on the central bank's board, he may soon prod it to do so as it prepares to raise interest rates to combat inflation.

title: Philip Jefferson in His Own Words
summary: One of Biden's picks for the Federal Reserve's board has focused on monetary policy and poverty issues. President Bidenhas nominatedPhilip Jefferson, the vice president for academic affairs and dean of faculty at Davidson College, to serve as a Federal Reserve Board governor. Previously an economics professor at Swarthmore College and an economist at the Fed, Mr. Jefferson's academic work has focused on monetary policy, poverty and inequality.

title: The New Clues About Who Will Develop Long Covid
summary: Research is homing in on risk factors for developing long Covid, offering clues for potential treatments. Asthma. Unhealthy gut bacteria. The presence of autoantibodies, usually associated with autoimmune conditions.

title: U.A.E. Shoots Down Missile Fired by Yemen's Houthis During Israeli Visit
summary: The intercepted strike was the third attack this month against the Emirati capital, Abu Dhabi. DUBAI-The United Arab Emirates military said Monday it intercepted a ballistic missile fired at Abu Dhabi by Iran-backed Houthi rebels in Yemen, just hours after Israel's president began a historic visit to the Persian Gulf country.

title: Fed's Policy Shift Ripples Through the Housing Market
summary: The central bank had been the biggest buyer of mortgage bonds, but now it is stepping back and borrowing costs are rising. The Federal Reserve's decision to end its era of easy money is rippling through the mortgage market, driving up the cost of buying a home.

title: Express Yourself (Monday Crossword, January 31)
The New Rules for Finding Your Next Job in 2022
summary: Candidates have more leverage. Conversations have shifted toward flexible hours and locations. How to ace your interview in this moment.. Workers are quitting in record numbers. Salaries are up, and flexibility is in. The rules for getting your next job have changed.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: The Rams Reach the Super Bowl With a Comeback Win Over the 49ers
summary: After a dozen years of losing in Detroit, Rams quarterback Matt Stafford made the most of his first year in L.A. by taking his team to a Super Bowl in its home stadium.. INGLEWOOD, Calif.-With a single trade last year, the Los Angeles Rams pinned the fate of their franchise to a loser. That might not be a fair description of Matthew Stafford, but it was long an accurate one for a player who languished for 12 dismal seasons in Detroit.

title: Foreign Journalists in China Say They Face Deepening Threats
summary: Many said they experienced harassment in the field when reporting, including from ordinary citizens who are increasingly hostile. HONG KONG-Foreign news organizations in China are operating at drastically reduced staffing levels, while the foreign journalists still in the country face intimidation, harassment and threats of legal action there, a Beijing-based journalist group said.

title: The Bengals Upset the Chiefs in Overtime to Reach the Super Bowl
summary: Cincinnati came back from down 21-3 to beat Patrick Mahomes and Kansas City and give the franchise a shot at its first-ever Super Bowl win.. KANSAS CITY, Mo.-The script seemed uncomfortably familiar. Patrick Mahomes led a game-tying drive to end regulation. Kansas City Chiefs won the coin toss to begin overtime.

title: Elliott and Vista Near Deal to Buy Citrix Systems
summary: Pair are close to an agreement to pay roughly $13 billion for the cloud-computing company. Cloud-computing company Citrix Systems Inc. is close to a roughly $13 billion deal to go private, continuing a spate of big leveraged buyouts that are powering record private-equity activity.
